Description: Solid-cast model of an arched sistrum in copper alloy, maybe a votive offering; Hathor head with prominent cow ears on the handle; two rods fixed on arch; maybe used as a fitting for a figure of Bastet; lower part broken off; corroded.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by World Museum, Liverpool. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This sacred musical instrument was particularly associated to the cult of Egyptian goddesses, notably Hathor, Isis, Bastet or Sekhmet (on sistra, see esp.: Hickmann 1949, p. 76-103, pl. XLV-LXX ; Pinch 1993, p. 143-146 ; Ziegler 1979, p. 31-62 ; Ziegler 1984). Naukratis provided several examples of sistra, in copper alloy like for this specimen, but also in glazed composition. Some of them can be dated to the 26th dynasty, supporting the practice of Egyptian cult activities in this period (Yoyotte 1994-95, 674; Masson forthcoming).
